body:
Comment 7: 
There is absolutely no reason Go should produce illegal output, even if it just so
happens to work. This is the kind of thinking that leads to all these "just so happens
to work" situations that plague Windows itself. Just search for compatibility on The Old
New Thing; the amount of work they have to do is incredible.

That being said, if wine wants to ensure total compatibility, they're going to need make
those very same concessions. From what I can gather, they /may/ fix it in the future if
it affects more than a just handful of programs. (THIS IS NOT AN INVITATION TO KEEP THE
BUG IN GO HOPING GO PROGRAMS WILL MAKE THEM CHANGE THEIR MIND.)

As it stands, both Go and wine are buggy for different reasons and from different
perspectives. Pointing fingers at each other does not make anything better for anyone.
(And this assumes that wine even /wants/ 100% compatibility with 100% of Windows
programs!)

So I'm standing with Alex on this issue: Go has a bug, and it should be fixed. I can
understand that it's too late now, but if Go's popularity is only going to grow, it will
need to be fixed eventually, even if no one using genuine Windows is ever going to see
it.
